importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Radule Bojovic's tourist visa expired in 2015, marking the start of his unlawful stay in the U.S.
The arrest of Officer Radule Bojovic by ICE occurred on October 17, 2025.
A similar immigration enforcement action took place in Iowa in September 2025, involving a school superintendent, highlighting a broader pattern of immigration enforcement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period from 2015 to 2025 represents the length of time Bojovic lived in the U.S. unlawfully, which is central to the immigration enforcement case.
The timeframe of the Iowa school superintendent’s alleged illegal stay (since early 2000s) shows a pattern of immigration enforcement targeting public officials.

keyTakeAways: ICE arrested a police officer, Radule Bojovic, in Hanover Park, Illinois, accusing him of overstaying a tourist visa that expired in 2015.
Bojovic, a graduate of the Suburban Law Enforcement Academy, was hired based on verified work authorization and no criminal history.
The Hanover Park Police Department confirmed due diligence checks by FBI and Illinois State Police prior to hiring.
DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin criticized the hiring of an officer living illegally in the U.S. as a violation of U.S. law and a breach of public trust.
Mayor Rodney Craig stated that village officials will monitor Bojovic’s immigration status and may return him to duty if authorized to remain.
The case parallels a similar 2025 arrest of an Iowa school superintendent, indicating a trend in immigration enforcement targeting public officials.
The incident raises questions about the vetting process for public employees and the potential for individuals to hold legal positions while violating immigration laws.

summaryOfNewsArticle: ICE arrested Radule Bojovic, a police officer from Montenegro, in Hanover Park, Illinois, accusing him of overstaying his tourist visa that expired in 2015, thereby living in the U.S. unlawfully for 10 years. Despite having undergone formal police training and passing background checks, Bojovic was hired based on verified work authorization. DHS officials, including Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin, criticized the hiring of an illegal alien with a firearm, calling it a breach of public trust. Hanover Park Mayor Rodney Craig affirmed the hiring process was thorough and compliant with due diligence, but stated that village officials will monitor Bojovic’s immigration status and may return him to duty if legally authorized. The case draws attention to broader immigration enforcement patterns, especially in targeting public officials, as seen in a similar arrest of a school superintendent in Iowa earlier in 2025.
title: ICE arrests police officer in Chicago suburb and accuses him of being in US illegally
